title: Isomorphic graphs
content: In the following, a general definition of the isomorphy relation for graphs and specializations for simple hypergraphs ( ~ isomushgr ) and simple pseudographs ( ~ isomuspgr ) are provided. The latter corresponds to the definition in [Bollobas] p. 3). It is shown that the isomorphy relation for graphs is an equivalence relation ( ~ isomgrref , ~ isomgrsym , ~ isomgrtr ). Fianlly, isomorphic graphs with different representations are studied ( ~ strisomgrop , ~ ushrisomgr ). Maybe more important than graph isomorphy is the notion of graph isomorphism, which can be defined as in ~ df-grisom . Then ` A IsomGr B <-> ` ` E. f f e. ( A GrIsom B ) ` resp. ` A IsomGr B <-> ( A GrIsom B ) =/= (/) `. Notice that there can be multiple isomorphisms between two graphs (let ` <. { A , B } , { { A , B } } >. ` and ` <. { { M , N } , { { M , N } } >. ` be two graphs with two vertices and one edge, then ` A |-> M , B |-> N ` and ` A |-> N , B |-> M ` are two different isomorphisms between these graphs). Another approach could be to define a category of graphs (there are maybe multiple ones), where graph morphisms are couples consisting in a function on vertices and a function on edges with required compatibilities, as used in the definition of ` GrIsom `. And then, a graph isomorphism is defined as an isomorphism in the category of graphs (something like "GraphIsom = ( Iso `` GraphCat )" ). Then general category theory theorems could be used, e.g., to show that graph isomorphy is an equivalence relation.

blocks.content: Define the class of all isomorphisms between two graphs. (Contributed by AV, 11-Dec-2022.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-grisom(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  |- wceq(cgrisom, cmpo(s0, s1, universe, universe, copab(s2, s3, w3a(wf1o(cv(s2), cfv(cvtx, cv(s0)), cfv(cvtx, cv(s1))), wf1o(cv(s3), cdm(cfv(ciedg, cv(s0))), cdm(cfv(ciedg, cv(s1)))), wral(s4, cdm(cfv(ciedg, cv(s0))), wceq(cima(cv(s2), cfv(cfv(ciedg, cv(s0)), cv(s4))), cfv(cfv(ciedg, cv(s1)), cfv(cv(s3), cv(s4)))))))))
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
}

axiom df-grisom(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  ‚ä¢ GrIsom =(s0 ‚àà ùïå, s1 ‚àà ùïå ‚Ü¶ { < s2, s3 > |((s2 :(Vtx ` s0)‚Üî(Vtx ` s1))‚àß(s3 : dom((iEdg ` s0))‚Üî dom((iEdg ` s1)))‚àß ‚àÄ(s4 ‚àà dom((iEdg ` s0)),(s2 "((iEdg ` s0)` s4))=((iEdg ` s1)`(s3 ` s4))))})
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s3, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
}

axiom df-isomgr(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  |- wceq(cisomgr, copab(s0, s1, wex(s2, wa(wf1o(cv(s2), cfv(cvtx, cv(s0)), cfv(cvtx, cv(s1))), wex(s3, wa(wf1o(cv(s3), cdm(cfv(ciedg, cv(s0))), cdm(cfv(ciedg, cv(s1)))), wral(s4, cdm(cfv(ciedg, cv(s0))), wceq(cima(cv(s2), cfv(cfv(ciedg, cv(s0)), cv(s4))), cfv(cfv(ciedg, cv(s1)), cfv(cv(s3), cv(s4)))))))))))
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
}

  ‚ä¢ IsomGr = { < s0, s1 > | ‚àÉ(s2,((s2 :(Vtx ` s0)‚Üî(Vtx ` s1))‚àß ‚àÉ(s3,((s3 : dom((iEdg ` s0))‚Üî dom((iEdg ` s1)))‚àß ‚àÄ(s4 ‚àà dom((iEdg ` s0)),(s2 "((iEdg ` s0)` s4))=((iEdg ` s1)`(s3 ` s4)))))))}

  ‚ä£ d(s2, s4)

  ‚ä£ d(s1, s3)

  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)

blocks.name: isisomgr
blocks.content: Implications of two graphs being isomorphic. (Contributed by AV, 11-Nov-2022.)
blocks.origin:
thm isisomgr(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5) {

  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cvtx, c0))
  -| wceq(c3, cfv(cvtx, c1))
  -| wceq(c4, cfv(ciedg, c0))
  -| wceq(c5, cfv(ciedg, c1))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c1)
  -| diffsc(s2, c0)
  -| diffsc(s2, c1)
  -| diffsc(s2, c4)
} = {
  ibi(wbr(c0, cisomgr, c1), wex(s0, wa(wf1o(cv(s0), c2, c3), wex(s1, wa(wf1o(cv(s1), cdm(c4), cdm(c5)), wral(s2, cdm(c4), wceq(cima(cv(s0), cfv(c4, cv(s2))), cfv(c5, cfv(cv(s1), cv(s2))))))))))
  syl(wbr(c0, cisomgr, c1), wb(wbr(c0, cisomgr, c1), wex(s0, wa(wf1o(cv(s0), c2, c3), wex(s1, wa(wf1o(cv(s1), cdm(c4), cdm(c5)), wral(s2, cdm(c4), wceq(cima(cv(s0), cfv(c4, cv(s2))), cfv(c5, cfv(cv(s1), cv(s2)))))))))), wa(wcel(c0, universe), wcel(c1, universe)))
  brrelex12i(c0, cisomgr, c1)
  isomgrrel()

}

blocks.name: isomuspgr
blocks.content: The isomorphy relation for two simple pseudographs. This corresponds to the definition in [Bollobas] p. 3. (Contributed by AV, 1-Dec-2022.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: isomgrref
blocks.content: The isomorphy relation is reflexive for hypergraphs. (Contributed by AV, 11-Nov-2022.)

blocks.name: isomgrsym

blocks.name: isomgrsymb
blocks.content: The isomorphy relation is symmetric for hypergraphs. (Contributed by AV, 11-Nov-2022.)

blocks.name: isomgrtr
blocks.content: The isomorphy relation is transitive for hypergraphs. (Contributed by AV, 5-Dec-2022.)

blocks.name: strisomgrop
blocks.content: A graph represented as an extensible structure with vertices as base set and indexed edges is isomorphic to a hypergraph represented as ordered pair with the same vertices and edges. (Contributed by AV, 11-Nov-2022.)
blocks.origin:
thm strisomgrop(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5) {
  |- wi(w3a(wcel(c0, cuhgr), wcel(c1, c2), wcel(c3, c4)), wbr(c0, cisomgr, c5))
  -| wceq(c0, cop(c1, c3))
  -| wceq(c5, cpr(cop(cfv(cbs, cnx), c1), cop(cfv(cedgf, cnx), c3)))
} = {
  syl22anc(w3a(wcel(c0, cuhgr), wcel(c1, c2), wcel(c3, c4)), wbr(c0, cisomgr, c5), wcel(c0, cuhgr), wcel(c5, universe), wceq(cfv(cvtx, c0), cfv(cvtx, c5)), wceq(cfv(ciedg, c0), cfv(ciedg, c5)))
  simp1(wcel(c0, cuhgr), wcel(c1, c2), wcel(c3, c4))
  a1i(w3a(wcel(c0, cuhgr), wcel(c1, c2), wcel(c3, c4)), wcel(c5, universe))

blocks.name: ushrisomgr
blocks.content: A simple hypergraph (with arbitrarily indexed edges) is isomorphic to a graph with the same vertices and the same edges, indexed by the edges themselves. (Contributed by AV, 11-Nov-2022.)
